Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Validated Multiscale Simulations of Ceramic Matrix Composites for Power Generation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objectives of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research project are to improve the understanding and to model the failure mechanisms of CMCs using an integrated approach based on novel multiscale computational methods and experimental validation. Revolutionary design of future power generation systems, rockets, and most recently, hypersonic missiles and flight vehicles are contingent on the development of advanced materials like ceramic matrix composites (CMCs), able to operate at high temperatures. A major challenge in the design of CMC components is the determination of the fracture behavior of these materials at relevant crack sizes for ceramic materials. Fracture of CMCs involves phenomena spanning several spatial scales from micron-size fibers to meter-size structural components. The University of Illinois will collaborate with researchers and engineers from General Electric Company to vigorously expand fundamental knowledge and modeling of damage mechanisms in CMCs.

This research offers an alternative for the difficult and costly fracture experiments needed to determine the fracture behavior of CMCs. If successful, it will allow validated simulations and improve the understanding of complex multiscale phenomena. This will pave the way for the solution of important engineering and scientific problems. While the focus of his research is on the problem of failure of CMCs, this multiscale framework may also have a direct impact on the modeling and understanding of other material systems and problems where existing multiscale methods are not applicable. This research program will enable the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students from the University of Illinois. These students will be involved in a multidisciplinary research topic that will foster critical interactions with researchers and engineers from General Electric Company. Another objective of this program is to motivate K-12 students to pursue an engineering degree. This will be achieved through the hands-on seminar Computational Mechanics, Engineering and Simulation Showcase (COME-&-SEE), showcasing the environmental and economical impact of computational engineering sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Revolutionary design of future power generation systems, rockets, and most recently, hypersonic missiles and flight vehicles are contingent on the development of advanced materials like ceramic matrix composites (CMCs), able to operate at high temperatures. A major challenge in the design of CMC components is the determination of the fracture behavior of these materials at relevant crack sizes for ceramic materials. Fracture of CMCs involves phenomena spanning several spatial scales—from micron-size fibers to meter-size structural components. The research component of this project focused on the development of computational methods able to perform virtual testing through computer simulations of materials with reinforcements like those found in CMCs. This type of simulations is quite challenging since the reinforcements are typically orders of magnitude smaller than typical engineering components such as a turbine blade. The new methods developed in this project has the potential of addressing existing barriers for the adoption of new classes of heterogeneous material in power generation systems for aircraft engines and land-based turbines. The high melting point of these materials enables the elevation of operating temperatures of these systems and therefore increases significantly their fuel efficiency. Their low density will further contribute to a reduction of fuel consumption in aircrafts. These gains in efficiency will in turn reduce the environmental impact and operating costs of aircrafts with clear societal benefits.

The educational component of this project enabled the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) and the professional development of a post-doctoral fellow. The students and post-doc were involved in a multidisciplinary research topic that fostered critical interactions with other students, faculty (from UIUC and Delft University of Technology in The Netherlands). Two of the undergraduate students involved in this project, one of them a minority student, are now pursuing graduate degrees in engineering. Both students have indicated that their decision to pursue graduate studies was strongly influenced by their positive research experience in this multidisciplinary project. Another outcome of the educational program was to motivate K-12 students to pursue an engineering degree. This was achieved through participation in the Girls Adventures in Mathematics, Engineering, and Science (GAMES) program. The GAMES summer camp is an annual one-week residential program conducted at UIUC and opened to academically talented high school girls (rising 9th-12th graders). The camp program was designed to give high school girls an opportunity to explore math, engineering, and science through demonstrations, classroom presentations, hand-on-activities, and contacts with people in these technical fields.
